channel.title: Most influential in games industry
channel.description:
Im sorry if this is in the wrong section(could you please move if this isn't the section), I couldn't determine exactly where it should go.
Sorry I saw this story online(http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2011-11-02-games-industry-votes-apple-as-biggest-influence?) and was like who are these people that they interviewed?

item.title: Most influential in games industry
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

But you can hardly call Rowling a big influence in English literature. I doubt she’ll ever receive a Nobel prize for her work.

Can’t you? I would, I think.

Besides, this was an industry award, not a Nobel prize. She has plenty of those, not to mention an OBE and whatever the French equivalent is. At least we didn’t knight Steve Jobs yet, haha.

Read full topic

item.title: Most influential in games industry
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

English literature is something that has spanned many hundreds of years, it isn’t a commercial industry, I don’t think they can be compared

The Verge – 10 Nov 11

iOS and Android now have lion's share of mobile gaming revenues, not just...

You won't be surprised to hear that most gaming on the move is now being done on smartphones, primarily of the iPhone and Android variety. What should raise an eyebrow, however, is the latest data...

item.title: Most influential in games industry
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

tL:

Then industry chases money, and the mobile industry for games is making a fuckload of it. Angry birds has been downloaded 500 million times.

I see your point, but I still don’t agree that Steve Jobs was a big influence in gaming industry. For instance, the Harry Potter series is selling great. But you can hardly call Rowling a big influence in English literature. I doubt she’ll ever receive a Nobel prize for her work.

Read full topic

item.title: Most influential in games industry
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:25, topic:420308”][quote author=tL link=topic=522864.msg3804396#msg3804396 date=1320331815]
But how many people wait for a train or a bus everyday? An absolute fuckload. I don’t play many games on my phone, and when I do, I stay away from the deeply involving ones.

But that is why it’s insanely successful, many people have these gaps of time to fill during their commute and a phone is something theyre carrying anyway.
[/quote]

But a game that’s meant to kill time is hardly a game you’d see as influential.[/quote]

Then industry chases money, and the mobile industry for games is making a fuckload of it. Angry birds has been downloaded 500 million times.

Read full topic

item.title: Most influential in games industry
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

In the computer gaming industry, it’s obvious this guy would by far be the most influential:

en.wikipedia.org

John Carmack

John D. Carmack (born August 20, 1970) is an American computer programmer, engineer, and businessman. He co-founded id Software. Carmack was the lead programmer of the id video games Commander Keen, Wolfenstein 3D, Doom, Quake, Rage and their sequels. Carmack is best known for his innovations in 3D graphics, such as his Carmack's Reverse algorithm for shadow volumes. In August 2013, Carmack took the position of CTO at Oculus VR. Carmack, son of local television news reporter Stan Carmack, grew ...

Read full topic

But that is why it’s insanely successful, many people have these gaps of time to fill during their commute and a phone is something theyre carrying anyway.[/quote]

item.title: Most influential in games industry
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

The mobile games market is absolutely massive, so Steve jobs is inevitably going to be influential in it, but, was this survey on the most influential of all time? Because I don’t really agree with putting Jobs and Apple at the top for that. If it was a poll for the present, then fair enough, Nintendo’s 3DS is falling short of all their sales expectations because of the new type of mobile gaming that was popularised by the iPhone, people aren’t that interested in dedicated handheld devices (which is a shame), and even Nintendo attributes their failure with the 3DS to the iPhone.

It’s why I think Sony is batshit insane to be coming out with the Vita at the price it is. If Nintendo can’t sell a handheld at that price, Sony sure can’t. But then, Sony doesn’t think common sense is all that cool these days.

Read full topic

item.description:

Mopman:

i still think we need to see the exact question that was asked

sure but the question is a bit redundant, apple may have a big impact on the gaming industry but it’s mostly localized to the iphone and to a lesser extent the mobile gaming industry

you could say whichever game bought 2 weapons max + regenerating health has a huge influence in the gaming industry but it’s localized to console and some pc fps games, it doesn’t really mean anything

item.title: Most influential in games industry
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

Nolan Bushnell

Nolan Kay Bushnell (born February 5, 1943) is an American electrical engineer and businessman. He established Atari, Inc. and the Chuck E. Cheese's Pizza Time Theatre chain. Bushnell has been inducted into the Video Game Hall of Fame and the Consumer Electronics Association Hall of Fame, received the BAFTA Fellowship and the Nations Restaurant News "Innovator of the Year" award, and was named one of Newsweek's "50 Men Who Changed America." Bushnell has started more than twenty companies and is on...


en.wikipedia.org

Ted Dabney

Ted Dabney is the co-founder of Syzygy and Atari. While working at Ampex Dabney met Nolan Bushnell and the two jointly created Syzygy with their first product being Computer Space, which was manufactured and sold by Nutting Associates. Following Computer Space, Ted Dabney's video circuit that was created for Computer Space was used by Al Alcorn to create Pong, with assistance from Dabney and Bushnell. Dabney remained out of the public eye after departing Atari and his role in creating the first c...

why are these guys not on that list?

E: and probably this guy too:

en.wikipedia.org

Allan Alcorn

Allan Alcorn (born January 1, 1948 in San Francisco) is an American pioneering engineer and computer scientist best known for creating Pong, one of the first video games. Alcorn grew up in San Francisco, California, and attended the University of California, Berkeley, graduating with a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences in 1971.

Read full topic
